attributes.alt: Book cover for Busy Builders, Busy Week! written by Jean Reidy and illustrated by Leo Timmers. The cover art shows animals working at a construction site.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to introduce the letters
, engage children with rhythm clapping, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What kind of trucks do these builders use?
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used.
What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?
What kinds of vehicles are in  that book?
Pretend you are playing an instrument! What will you play?
Can you draw a playground with swings? How many swings did you draw? Let’s count and see  if we can match a counter to each one.
Can you write a song about cars?
What part of the playground do you like best? Draw it.
in the pile of Magnetic Letters?
What can you use to make a truck? Let’s try!

attributes.alt: Book cover for Busy Builders, Busy Week! written by Jean Reidy and illustrated by Leo Timmers. The cover art shows animals working at a construction site.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Imagination Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about when the author and illustrator are using their imaginations.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used.
Encourage children to use their imaginations and persist in the task of building a part of a pretend playground.
Invite children to make a portion of a playground to contribute to the whole.
What kinds of trucks and big machines do you see? How do they help us?
Do you think the author of that book has a good imagination?
Use your imagination to pretend you are a character in
How many different kinds of big machines for building do you see in our book? Let’s use counters and see if we can match them!
Show me how you write your name on my dry-erase board.
Can you sculpt an imaginary animal? What does it look like?
Let’s make a race track for our cars and trucks! Then we can take turns racing.

attributes.alt: Book cover for Busy Builders, Busy Week! written by Jean Reidy and illustrated by Leo Timmers. The cover art shows animals working at a construction site.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to study materials from the earth, identify rhymes, and introduce the vocabulary
How do the builders use materials from the earth?
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used.
Help children identify pictures of things that go.
Invite children to make connections between the things that go.
What vehicles can you talk about? How do they help us?
Why do you like this book?
How can you pretend to be a builder? Let’s see.
Which animal builder is your favorite? What do you know about that animal?
How can you write a story about what you like to do at the playground?
How can you use materials to make a construction vehicle?
What letter begins the word insect? Can you write it?
How can we make a seesaw? What materials can we use?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for The Wheels on the Bus. There are six pictures: a bus with the words "round and round"; an airplane with the words "swoosh, swoosh, swoosh"; a car with the words "beep, beep, beep"; a boat with the words "splash, splash, splash"; a train with the words "chug, chug, chug"; and a backhoe with the words "dig, dig, dig.
Book cover for Busy Builders, Busy Week! written by Jean Reidy and illustrated by Leo Timmers. The cover art shows animals working at a construction site.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to have fun with rhymes and introduce vocabulary words
Read closely to answer the weekly concept questions,
What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?
Use imagination to think about or picture something.

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for The Wheels on the Bus. There are six pictures: a bus with the words "round and round"; an airplane with the words "swoosh, swoosh, swoosh"; a car with the words "beep, beep, beep"; a boat with the words "splash, splash, splash"; a train with the words "chug, chug, chug"; and a backhoe with the words "dig, dig, dig.

elements.text: Invite children to listen for and identify words that rhyme.
What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?
Compare this story to The Wheels on the Bus.
Let’s all pretend we are riding a bus together. I’ll be the driver! Who are you? Where are you going?
Can you put the animals in this book in order from biggest to smallest?
Let’s write a thank-you note to the builders for the park! Tell me what to write.
Make a painting. Dip small toy cars and trucks into paint and roll them on paper.
What letter begins the word jacket? Can you write it?
Let’s build three slides: big, bigger, biggest. We can use blocks, bricks or other materials!

attributes.alt: Book cover for Busy Builders, Busy Week! written by Jean Reidy and illustrated by Leo Timmers. The cover art shows animals working at a construction site.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to act out and pretend and introduce the new vocabulary word
What do the builders do each day?
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
How do vehicles help us get from place to place?
Save children’s work to display next week.
What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?
Imagine you were in this book! What would you say and do?
Pretend you are a scientist. What would you like to study?
Let’s sort our objects from nature. Which came from trees? Which came from the earth?
Make up a story about a pretend car that can talk. Draw a picture and write what the car says. I’ll help. Then share your story.
Let’s paint these rocks to look like bugs! Will that turn the rocks into living things?
Create a new ride for a playground. Make it using bricks or blocks.
